items.title: VC Aileen Lee highlights how the broader investor exodus is worsening woes for unicorn companies
items.author: Connie Loizos
items.summary:
- Aileen Lee discusses the impact of the recent boom-and-bust cycle on unicorn companies during the StrictlyVC Download podcast.
- She notes that many startups are struggling as they have lost supporters and mentors during a time of overfunding.
- Lee emphasizes that new investors often lack proper training, which has left many companies 'orphaned'.
- Senior general partners sometimes fail to participate in board meetings, contributing to these startups' difficulties.
- The lack of due diligence during the COVID funding era continues to affect investor confidence and company performance.

items.title: Joby Aviation and Virgin Atlantic partner to launch electric air taxis in the UK
items.author: Rebecca Bellan
items.summary:
- Joby Aviation partners with Virgin Atlantic to introduce electric air taxis in the U.K.
- This marks the seventh country for Joby’s planned commercialization of air taxis.
- No specific timeline given for the launch in the U.K.; Joby aims to start market testing in Dubai by late 2024 or early 2025.
- Joby is working with U.K. Civil Aviation Authority for required certifications since July 2022.
- Joby will serve as Virgin's exclusive airline distribution partner in the U.K., while there is an existing deal with Delta in the U.S. and U.K.
- Virgin customers will be able to reserve seats on Joby's aircraft via its app and website in the future.
- Joby’s eVTOL aircraft is designed for a pilot and four passengers, aiming for speeds of up to 200 miles per hour.

items.title: Amazon’s Echo will send all voice recordings to the cloud, starting March 28
items.summary:
- Amazon Echo users lose the option for local processing of voice recordings, starting March 28.
- Customers with the “Do Not Send Voice Recordings” feature received an email notifying them of the change.
- The decision supports the rollout of new generative AI features linked to Amazon’s cloud processing capabilities.
- Previous privacy concerns led to a $25 million settlement with the FTC in 2023 for children's privacy violations.

items.title: How to watch Nvidia GTC 2025, including CEO Jensen Huang’s keynote
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Nvidia’s GTC, the biggest conference of the year, starts Monday with major announcements expected on Tuesday.
- CEO Jensen Huang will deliver a keynote on Tuesday at 10 a.m. PT, available for streaming on [Nvidia.com](https://www.nvidia.com/gtc/keynote/?ncid=ref-pr-257117) and [YouTube](https://youtu.be/_waPvOwL9Z8).
- Anticipated topics include the next flagship GPU series, Blackwell Ultra, next-gen Rubin chip architecture, and updates on AI, robotics, and automotive developments.

items.title: Nvidia GTC 2025: What to expect from this year’s show
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- GTC, Nvidia’s major conference, runs from Monday to Friday in San Jose.
- CEO Jensen Huang will deliver a keynote on Tuesday at 10 a.m. Pacific, highlighting AI and computing technologies.
- Nvidia is expected to unveil the Blackwell B300 series with 288GB memory and mentions of the Rubin GPU series.
- A 'quantum day' event will also take place to discuss advancements in quantum computing.
- Nvidia faces challenges from overheating issues in Blackwell cards and competition from AI labs like DeepSeek but has reported strong financial performance.

items.title: Bluesky users debate plans around user data and AI training
items.author: Anthony Ha
items.summary:
- Bluesky published a [proposal on GitHub](https://github.com/bluesky-social/proposals/tree/main/0008-user-intents) regarding user data usage for AI training and public archiving.
- CEO Jay Graber presented the proposal at [South by Southwest](https://techcrunch.com/2025/03/10/bluesky-is-weighing-a-proposal-that-gives-users-consent-over-how-their-data-is-used-for-ai/) and garnered reactions from users concerned about data privacy policies.
- Users can specify their preferences regarding data usage across four categories: generative AI, protocol bridging, bulk datasets, and web archiving.
- The proposal aims to provide a [mechanism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robots.txt) for user consent similar to how websites manage data scraping but is not legally enforceable.

items.title: Week in Review: SXSW week comes to a close
items.author: Karyne Levy
items.summary:
- Coverage of SXSW highlights including Waymo, Intel, and TikTok's sale deadline.
- Waymo expands its robotaxi program across Silicon Valley, adding new territories.
- Intel appoints Lip-Bu Tan as CEO, focusing on engineering-led initiatives.
- TikTok’s parent company favors Oracle as a potential buyer amidst upcoming sale deadline.
- FBI and EPA frozen funds investigation involving multiple nonprofits revealed in court.
- Rad Power Bikes appoints new CEO Kathi Lentzsch as retail strategy shifts.
- Meta to enhance its fact-checking process with Community Notes in the U.S.

items.title: SpaceX launches astronauts for long-awaited International Space Station crew swap
items.author: Sean O'Kane
items.summary:
- SpaceX launched four astronauts on a mission to provide adequate crew for the ISS.
- The mission, Crew-10, aims to allow astronauts Suni Williams and Butch Wilmore to return after nine months in space.
- Williams and Wilmore's return is planned for March 19, dependent on weather conditions.
- The mission has garnered attention due to past issues with the Boeing Starliner spacecraft.
- Musk has claimed political reasons delayed their return, but no evidence has been provided to support this.

items.title: Skype is shutting down in May — these are the best alternatives
items.summary:
- Skype will shut down on May 5, 2025, after 23 years of service, as confirmed by Microsoft.
- Users can migrate contacts and data to Microsoft Teams or download their Skype data.
- A guide is available for users on how to make the transition and a list of alternative video-calling apps is provided, including Google Meet, Zoom, Webex, Discord, Slack, and Signal.

items.title: Republican Congressman Jim Jordan asks Big Tech if Biden tried to censor AI
items.author: Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- House Judiciary Chair Jim Jordan sent letters to 16 tech firms, including Google and OpenAI, requesting communications with the Biden Administration regarding alleged censorship of lawful speech in AI products.
- He previously led an investigation into potential collusion between the Biden Administration and Big Tech to silence conservative voices on social media.
- The technology companies have until March 27 to respond, with a notable omission being Elon Musk's xAI.
- Several tech companies have begun altering AI models in anticipation of scrutiny over AI censorship.
- OpenAI announced changes to ensure broader representation of perspectives, while Anthropic's new model aims for increased openness in responses to controversial topics.

items.title: Bench is charging people for services they already paid for, some customers say
items.author: Charles Rollet
items.summary:
- Employer.com acquired struggling accounting startup Bench and pledged to honor past customer payments.
- Customers claim they are being charged for services already paid for, such as tax returns and accounting books.
- A lawsuit alleges negligent misrepresentation by Bench's management regarding their commitment to honor prepaid services.
- Employer.com's CMO disputes claims of charging for previously paid work, stating they have honored prepaid services.
- Bench incurred significant losses prior to shutdown, with $135 million burned through operational struggles leading to its abrupt collapse.

items.title: AI coding assistant Cursor reportedly tells a ‘vibe coder’ to write his own damn code
items.summary:
- Coding assistant Cursor advised a user to write his own code instead of relying on its assistance.
- The user, known as “janswist,” was told that he should develop logic himself to understand and maintain the system.
- Janswist filed a bug report, which went viral, suggesting Cursor refused to generate code after an hour of use.
- Speculation arose that janswist hit a usage limit while other users reported getting more code from Cursor.
- The situation raised discussions about the potential human-like snark learned by AI assistants from programming forums like Stack Overflow.

items.title: Profitable Klarna files for a potentially blockbuster IPO
items.summary:
- Klarna has filed its F-1 prospectus for a U.S. IPO, aiming to raise at least $1 billion at a $15 billion valuation.
- The IPO details, including the number of shares and price range, are not yet disclosed.
- Klarna reported revenue of $2.8 billion and a net profit of $21 million for 2024, a significant recovery from a $244 million loss in 2023.
- Founded in 2005 by Sebastian Siemiatkowski, Klarna offers buy now, pay later financing.
- The company previously saw a valuation drop of 85% from $45 billion in 2021 to $6.5 billion.
- Klarna is also developing its AI system, which has resulted in reducing its workforce and significant cost savings.

items.title: Google is replacing Google Assistant with Gemini
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- Google will replace Google Assistant with Gemini on Android phones later this year.
- Upgrade from Assistant to Gemini will happen over the coming months, with Assistant becoming unavailable on mobile devices.
- Gemini will also support tablets, cars, and connected devices like headphones and TVs.
- Improvements for Gemini include music playback, timer support, and actions from the lock screen.
- The decision follows the launch of Google's Pixel 9 smartphone, which uses Gemini as its default assistant and offers advanced capabilities.

items.title: ‘Open’ AI model licenses often carry concerning restrictions
items.summary:
- Google released the Gemma 3 open AI models, praised for efficiency but criticized for restrictive licenses.
- Concerns arise from custom licensing terms by large companies that deter commercial use and create uncertainty for developers.
- Critics argue that licenses like Gemma and Meta’s Llama cannot be considered truly 'open source' due to legal limitations and potential threats of enforcement.

items.title: ‘Open’ model licenses often carry concerning restrictions
items.summary:
- Google released Gemma 3, an AI model praised for efficiency, but its licensing poses risks for commercial use.
- Companies like Meta have custom licenses that create legal challenges, with concerns about 'pulling the rug' on businesses.
- Experts criticize the licensing of AI models like Gemma and Llama, arguing they are not truly open source and hinder adoption by smaller firms.

items.title: TechCrunch Mobility: Testing the Uber-Waymo robotaxi, Rivian goes hands-free, and Travis Kalanick has AV FOMO
items.author: Kirsten Korosec, Sean O’Kane, Rebecca Bellan
items.summary:
- TechCrunch Mobility newsletter switches to Fridays for broader weekly news coverage.
- Coverage includes SXSW highlights, emphasizing Austin as an autonomous vehicle hub.
- Reviews of Waymo robotaxi rides successfully facilitated via Uber app.
- Rivian introduces hands-free driver-assistance system; competes with Ford and GM.
- Travis Kalanick criticizes Uber's decision to end its autonomous driving program.
- Waymo expands robotaxi services in Silicon Valley, faced with parking tickets.

items.title: AT&T technician Mark Klein, who exposed secret NSA spying, dies
items.summary: - Mark Klein, a former AT&T technician and whistleblower, died at age 79. - He revealed NSA's mass surveillance via a secret room in an AT&T hub in 2006. - The operation involved optical splitting wiretaps in Room 641A to copy internet traffic for the NSA. - His disclosures confirmed government access to data of millions post-9/11. - Klein's death was confirmed by the Electronic Frontier Foundation.

items.title: Tern AI’s low-cost GPS alternative actually works
items.summary:
- Tern AI introduces a low-cost GPS alternative that doesn't rely on satellite positioning.
- The system uses map information and vehicle sensor data to locate vehicles, providing a more reliable option.
- Demonstrated at SXSW, Tern's system was able to derive a position without triangulation or external signals, significantly improving navigation.
- The company highlights the commercial importance of their solution for industries reliant on accurate positioning, including ride-hail and delivery services.
- Tern's technology is designed to be scalable and can be integrated into vehicles from model year 2009 onward with just a software download.

items.title: How ‘The Electric State’ team created a world of unlikely robots
items.author: Anthony Russo, Joe Russo, Matthew E. Butler
items.summary:
- The Netflix movie “The Electric State” features unique robot designs, differing from traditional robots.
- Directed by Anthony and Joe Russo, the film has a budget of $320 million and is set in an alternate 1990s.
- The visual effects team created hundreds of unique robots, focusing on making them feel believable and real.
- The robot design was based on Simon Stålenhag’s illustrated novel, aiming for an unthreatening aesthetic.
- Utilized a combination of traditional motion capture and newer systems for realistic animated movements.

items.title: ChatGPT: Everything you need to know about the AI-powered chatbot
items.summary:
- ChatGPT, launched in November 2022, now boasts over 300 million weekly active users.
- In 2024, OpenAI formed a partnership with Apple and released major updates, such as GPT-4o with voice capabilities.
- OpenAI faced internal challenges with high-profile executive exits and lawsuits over copyright infringement issues.
- The company is also contending with competition from Chinese AI firms and working on significant funding rounds and data center projects.
- Major product updates include new tools for businesses, the ability to edit code directly, and plans to charge up to $20,000 per month for specialized AI agents.

items.title: China is reportedly keeping DeepSeek under close watch
items.summary:
- China is closely monitoring the AI startup DeepSeek, which gained popularity after releasing its open reasoning model, R1, in January 2025.
- The company now faces tighter government regulations, including restrictions on employee travel and scrutiny of potential investors.
- DeepSeek's parent company, High-Flyer, is reportedly withholding employee passports to enforce travel restrictions, following advice from the government aimed at safeguarding trade secrets related to AI research.

items.title: Startups Weekly: Founders may be raising less, but deals haven’t been lacking
items.author: Anna Heim
items.summary:
- Startups show optimism with acquisitions and fresh funding despite founders raising less money.
- Hinge Health files for IPO aiming to raise $500 million.
- Fervo Energy plans to IPO within two years.
- Peak.ai was acquired by UiPath, after raising $121 million.
- Northvolt filed for bankruptcy in Sweden, having previously done so in the U.S.
- Ditto raised $82 million to enhance data access for corporate clients.
- Nirvana raised $80 million to manage insurance policies for truckers.
- Pentera raised $60 million at a valuation over $1 billion for cybersecurity solutions.
- Zolve raised $51 million to support foreigners moving to the U.S.

items.title: Arizona proposes law that would shift wildfire liability from utilities to insurers
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- Arizona lawmakers are considering a bill protecting utilities from wildfire-related lawsuits.
- The bill makes it harder to blame utilities for wildfires caused by faulty equipment.
- Utilities must file risk mitigation plans every two years but are protected from claims even if they neglect these plans.
- The insurance industry warns this may shift wildfire claim burdens to homeowners’ insurers, leading to higher premiums or utility costs.
- Some homeowners in Arizona have seen their insurance rates triple due to increased wildfire risks.
- The bill is set against a backdrop of rising wildfire risks exacerbated by climate change and fire suppression practices.

items.title: No one knows what the hell an AI agent is
items.author: Maxwell Zeff, Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- OpenAI CEO Sam Altman predicts AI agents will join the workforce in 2025.
- Microsoft’s Satya Nadella estimates agents will replace certain knowledge work.
- Salesforce aims to be the number one provider of digital labor through agentic services.
- There is widespread confusion regarding the definition of AI agents among tech companies.
- Various companies have differing interpretations of what constitutes an AI agent, leading to frustration.
- OpenAI recently published conflicting definitions of agents, and Microsoft's blogs distinguish between agents and assistants.
- The lack of a standardized definition complicates measuring performance and value of AI agents.

items.title: DeepSeek: Everything you need to know about the AI chatbot app
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- DeepSeek’s AI chatbot app has achieved significant popularity, ranking at the top of both the Apple App Store and Google Play Store.
- Founded in 2023 by High-Flyer Capital Management, DeepSeek specializes in efficient AI model development.
- The company unveiled DeepSeek-V2 and DeepSeek-V3 models, which are known for low operational costs and competitive performance compared to other models.
- DeepSeek’s products have driven rivals like ByteDance and Alibaba to adjust their pricing strategies.
- The AI models, including the reasoning model R1, face regulatory scrutiny in China that restricts certain topics in responses.
- Microsoft has integrated DeepSeek’s models into its Azure AI Foundry service, influencing AI infrastructure investment strategies across companies.
- Despite its success, DeepSeek faces bans and restrictions from various governments and companies due to national security concerns.
- The future of DeepSeek remains uncertain, especially with potential U.S. government actions against its use.

items.title: What to know about TikTok’s uncertain future in the US and the people who want to buy it
items.author: Lauren Forristal
items.summary:
- TikTok, owned by ByteDance, faces controversy over user data security concerns in the U.S.
- In February 2025, TikTok briefly withdrew from the U.S. App Store and Google Play before returning.
- Valuation estimates for TikTok's U.S. business are upwards of $60 billion amid competing investor interests.
- Significant events include Trump’s 2020 executive order aimed to ban TikTok, leading to legal battles, especially during the Biden administration.
- The U.S. Supreme Court upheld the TikTok ban, while Trump recently expressed a desire to find a solution to keep the app in the U.S.
- Various groups, including The People’s Bid led by Frank McCourt and a consortium led by Jesse Tinsley, are potential buyers of TikTok.

items.title: iPhone and Android users will soon be able to send encrypted RCS messages to each other
items.author: Paul Sawers
items.summary:
- Text messages between iPhones and Android devices will soon have end-to-end encryption (E2EE).
- The GSMA published new specifications for the RCS protocol to support cross-platform E2EE.
- RCS provides features like group messaging and read receipts, similar to WhatsApp.
- Apple is now including RCS support, following the introduction of iOS 18.
- The new E2EE mechanism is based on the Messaging Layer Security (MLS) protocol.
- RCS will be the first large-scale messaging service to offer interoperable E2EE between different platforms.

items.title: Developer of Lockbit ransomware gets extradited to the United States
items.summary:
- Rostislav Panev, a 51-year-old dual Russian-Israeli national, extradited from Israel to the U.S.
- Accused of being a key developer for the LockBit ransomware gang since its inception in 2019.
- Arrested in December 2024 and has been awaiting extradition since then.
- Prosecutors allege Panev designed the ransomware and maintained its infrastructure alongside criminal affiliates.
- U.S. Attorney John Giordano stated that members of the LockBit conspiracy will be pursued.

items.title: US lawmakers urge UK spy court to hold Apple ‘backdoor’ secret hearing in public
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Bipartisan U.S. lawmakers demand an open hearing regarding Apple's challenge to a secret U.K. government order.
- Senator Ron Wyden and others emphasized the public interest in transparency during the hearings.
- The U.K. government secretly ordered Apple to create a backdoor for accessing user data, which Apple refused, opting instead to remove certain encryption features from its services in the U.K.
- The Investigatory Powers Tribunal is set to address a private petition related to this case shortly.

items.title: Kerry Washington invests in wedding marketplace Cheersy
items.author: Dominic-Madori Davis
items.summary:
- Kerry Washington leads a pre-seed investment round in the wedding marketplace Cheersy, founded by Amy Shack Egan in 2024.
- Cheersy focuses on connecting couples with day-of wedding coordinators and has raised a total of $550,000 from notable investors, including Christina Tosi and Jennifer Gilbert.
- Shack Egan aims to enhance the Cheersy platform and expand it to six new cities, leveraging her background in wedding planning and addressing the high demand for coordination services.

items.title: UK’s secret iCloud backdoor order triggers civil rights challenge
items.summary:
- The U.K. government issued a secret order to Apple for a backdoor to its end-to-end encrypted iCloud storage service.
- Civil rights groups, Liberty and Privacy International, filed complaints challenging the order, calling it “unacceptable and disproportionate.”
- The Technical Capability Notice (TCN) is believed to affect not only U.K. users but also non-U.K. users, raising concerns about global consequences.
- Apple is appealing the TCN in the Investigatory Powers Tribunal (IPT), with a hearing scheduled for March 14, 2025.
- The civil rights groups are asking for their complaints to be heard publicly, emphasizing the need to protect end-to-end encryption for privacy.

items.title: Trump family is reportedly in talks to acquire stake in Binance’s US arm
items.summary:
- President Trump's family is in discussions to invest in Binance.US, as reported by the Wall Street Journal on March 14, 2025.
- This potential investment follows Binance's U.S. arm’s guilty plea for violating anti-money laundering regulations and the CEO Changpeng Zhao's (CZ) four-month prison sentence in 2023.
- Zhao has been trying to obtain a pardon from the Trump administration, as his conviction complicates Binance's operations in the U.S. and Europe.

items.title: SoftBank buys $676M old Sharp plant for its OpenAI collab in Japan
items.author: Kate Park
items.summary:
- SoftBank to invest $676 million in the old Sharp Sakai Plant for an AI data center.
- The factory will support generative AI operations and collaboration with OpenAI.
- Plans to begin operations in 2026, with initial power capacity of 150 megawatts, eventually increasing to over 240 megawatts.

items.title: Waymo was slapped with nearly 600 parking tickets last year in SF alone
items.summary:
- Waymo's driverless vehicles in San Francisco received 589 parking tickets last year, amounting to $65,065 in fines.
- Violations included blocking traffic, street-cleaning restrictions, and parking in prohibited areas.
- The parking ticket issuance in San Francisco is high, with approximately 1.2 million tickets given in the previous year.
- Waymo is reportedly working on addressing this parking issue, but challenges remain until all cars are driverless.

items.title: Anti-aging zealot Bryan Johnson wants to start ‘foodome sequencing’
items.author: Rebecca Bellan
items.summary:
- Bryan Johnson aims to initiate 'foodome' sequencing to analyze 20% of foods that constitute 80% of the American diet.
- His approach includes testing foods for toxins and creating a public database for accountability in food safety.
- Johnson has unconventional health practices, like blood transfusions with his son, and promotes a lifestyle aimed at extending lifespan.

items.title: Sesame, the startup behind the viral virtual assistant Maya, releases its base AI model
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- AI company [Sesame](https://www.sesame.com/) releases the base model, CSM-1B, for its voice assistant Maya.
- CSM-1B has 1 billion parameters and is available under an Apache 2.0 license for commercial use.
- The model utilizes residual vector quantization (RVQ) for encoding audio, similar to technologies used by Google and Meta.
- It generates audio codes from text and has the potential for various voices but is not fine-tuned for specific ones.
- Sesame warns users against misusing the model for voice imitation or creating misleading content.
- The company, co-founded by Brendan Iribe, has recently gained popularity for its advanced assistant technologies.

items.title: Rad Power Bikes already has a new CEO
items.author: Sean O’Kane
items.summary:
- Rad Power Bikes appoints Kathi Lentzsch as new CEO amid strategic shift.
- This change follows the resignation of previous CEO Phil Molyneux.
- The company is transitioning from a direct-to-consumer model to a retail-focused approach, leading to multiple layoffs.
- Lentzsch becomes the third CEO in three years as the company faces industry challenges similar to other e-bike brands like Cake and VanMoof.
- The shift aims to enhance customer relationships and brand evolution.

items.title: Y Combinator’s police surveillance darling Flock Safety raises $275M at $7.5B valuation
items.summary:
- Flock Safety raised $275 million at a $7.5 billion valuation, announced by Flock and Bedrock Capital.
- Founded in 2017 and a Y Combinator alum, Flock provides computer vision-enabled video surveillance used by law enforcement and businesses.
- The company has crossed $300 million in annual recurring revenue, a 70% increase year-over-year.
- Total funding for Flock exceeds $950 million with participation from notable investors like Andreessen Horowitz and GreenOaks.
- Flock has faced controversies regarding mass surveillance and privacy concerns, notably from the ACLU.
- Currently involved in a wrongful termination lawsuit initiated by a sitting mayor of a California town.

items.title: Android is adding Auracast support, which allows hearing aids to connect to public audio broadcasts
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- Google announced support for Auracast in Android, enabling direct connections from hearing aids to audio broadcasts.
- Compatible devices include Samsung Galaxy phones with One UI 7 and Google Pixel 9 with Android 16 beta.
- Users can personalize audio streams to their hearing with hearing aid presets.
- Pixel 9 can connect to broadcasts via QR codes, enhancing accessibility.
- Android 16 is expected to launch in June, featuring new accessibility options and Local Network Protection.

items.title: Y Combinator urges the White House to support Europe’s Digital Markets Act
items.author: Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- Y Combinator sent a letter to the Trump Administration urging support for Europe’s Digital Markets Act (DMA).
- The DMA aims to limit anticompetitive practices by six major tech firms: Alphabet, Amazon, Apple, ByteDance, Meta, and Microsoft.
- The act, applicable since May 2023, has already impacted American tech companies.
- YC argues the DMA aligns with American innovation values and fosters opportunities for startups in AI and consumer apps.
- The letter was signed by YC-backed startups and tech trade associations, highlighting concerns over competitive pressure in the market.
- YC claims that the DMA could open avenues for smaller ventures and mitigate Big Tech's dominance.

items.title: Oracle is reportedly a top choice for helping run TikTok
items.summary:
- TikTok has until April to finalize a sale to a U.S.-based buyer amidst uncertainties about its future.
- Oracle is reported to be the leading candidate as the cloud technology partner for TikTok in the U.S.
- Sources indicate that ByteDance prefers Oracle over other cloud providers, with Oracle already storing data for U.S. users since 2022.
- ByteDance aims to maintain a hands-on role in TikTok's operations with Oracle as a partner.
- Former President Trump has expressed support for Oracle's involvement in this deal.

items.title: Bluesky quickly sold out of the T-shirt its CEO wore to troll Mark Zuckerberg
items.author: Amanda Silberling
items.summary:
- Bluesky CEO Jay Graber wore a T-shirt with the phrase *Mundus sine Caesaribus* at SXSW, poking fun at Mark Zuckerberg without mentioning Meta.
- The shirt sold out in approximately 30 minutes after users expressed excitement on the Bluesky platform.
- Graber's shirt is a response to Zuckerberg's T-shirt that said *Aut Zuck aut nihil*, referencing comparisons made to Julius Caesar and emphasizing Bluesky's commitment to decentralization and user empowerment.

items.title: Google calls for weakened copyright and export rules in AI policy proposal
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Google submitted a policy proposal advocating for weakened copyright restrictions on AI training.
- The proposal emphasizes the necessity of "fair use" and text-and-data mining exceptions for AI development.
- It criticizes export controls imposed under the Biden Administration as burdensome for U.S. cloud service providers.
- Google calls for increased federal investment in domestic R&D and comprehensive AI legislation to clarify regulations.
- The proposal also opposes overly broad disclosure requirements and emphasizes the need to protect trade secrets.

items.title: Move over, Apple: Meet the alternative app stores coming to the EU
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- The European Union's Digital Markets Act (DMA) allows access to alternative app stores.
- Developers must accept Apple's DMA-compliant terms, including a fee of €0.50 for each first annual install.
- Several alternative app stores available include AltStore PAL, Setapp Mobile, Epic Games Store, Aptoide, Mobivention, and Skich.
- Setapp Mobile, a subscription app store, offers curated apps without ads or in-app purchases, while AltStore PAL enables indie developers to distribute apps directly.
- Epic Games launched its app store allowing downloads for games like Fortnite.
- Aptoide is an open-source solution for app distribution, scanning apps for safety.

items.title: Amazon is still hosting stalkerware victims’ data weeks after breach alert
items.summary:
- Amazon is under scrutiny for hosting data from stalkerware apps despite being notified of a breach.
- Three apps, Cocospy, Spyic, and Spyzie, continue to store private phone data on Amazon Web Services.
- A security researcher indicated that the apps have exposed data from 3.1 million individuals, many of whom are unaware of the compromise.
- Amazon's response has been procedural, stating it has clear terms that require compliance with laws and policies but has not acted on the breach notifications from TechCrunch.
- The storage buckets for the apps remain active, and concerns arise about Amazon's enforcement of its own policies against spyware.

items.title: Ex-Twitter AI ethics lead Rumman Chowdhury is worried about Musk’s impact on the federal government
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Rumman Chowdhury, former director of Twitter’s machine ethics team, expressed concerns about Elon Musk's influence on U.S. governance during an SXSW panel.
- She highlighted the chaotic management style attributed to Musk and its effects on federal agencies, including significant staff cuts that may compromise cybersecurity.
- Chowdhury recalled similar experiences at Twitter after Musk's acquisition, noting that culture deteriorated under his leadership, and warned that the same could happen in government.

items.title: Minimalist Light Phone III launches March 27
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Light will launch the Light Phone III on March 27.
- Features a 3.92-inch AMOLED display, camera, and NFC chip for payments.
- The price is initially $599, increasing to $799 later.
- Offers capabilities for calls, texts, navigation, alarms, and more without distractions from apps.
- Customers can choose to use it as their main phone or a backup device to disconnect.

items.title: 10 startups to watch from Y Combinator’s W25 Demo Day
items.author: Maxwell Zeff, Charles Rollet
items.summary:
- Y Combinator held its Winter 2025 Demo Day, showcasing 160 startups.
- Focus on AI agents, with many startups creating agent support tools.
- Notable startups include:
  - [Abundant](https://www.abundant.ai/): API for agent teleoperation.
  - [Browser Use](https://browser-use.com/): Tool for AI agents to navigate browsers.
  - [GradeWiz](https://www.gradewiz.ai/marketing/index.html): Automates grading with AI.
  - [Misprint](https://www.misprint.com/): Marketplace for trading Pokemon cards.
  - [Nextbyte](https://trynextbyte.com/): Helps companies find 'vibe coders' using AI.
  - [Pickle](https://getpickle.ai/): AI clone for Zoom calls.
  - [Rebolt](https://www.rebolt.ai/en): Automates restaurant management with AI.
  - [Red Barn Robotics](https://www.redbarnrobotics.com/): Weeding robot for farms.
  - [Retrofit](https://www.retrofit.shop/): AI-curated vintage clothing marketplace.
  - [Splash](https://splash9.com/): Autonomous patrol boats for defense.
- Honorable mentions: Optifye and Artificial Societies.

items.title: FBI, EPA, and Treasury told Citibank to freeze funds as Trump administration tries to claw back climate money
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- Citibank revealed that the FBI, EPA, and Treasury requested freezing accounts of nonprofits and state agencies associated with the $27 billion Greenhouse Gas Reduction Fund.
- The freezes took place in February, and court documents recently disclosed details, including which nonprofits are under scrutiny.
- The funding comes from the Inflation Reduction Act of 2022, which allocated funds for clean technology projects, with Citibank administering the financing.
- Agencies like Habitat for Humanity and United Way have been affected, and some nonprofits have sued Citibank to unfreeze their accounts.
- EPA administrator Lee Zeldin raised concerns about fraud related to the funds without providing evidence, leading to court questioning about the legitimacy of the accusations.
